DataElement.preferredName: Invasive Breast Carcinoma Histologically Confirmed Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator related to confirmed histology for marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue for cancer that forms in tissues of the breast, usually the ducts (tubes that carry milk to the nipple) and lobules (glands that make milk).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to confirmed histology for marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue for cancer that forms in tissues of the breast, usually the ducts (tubes that carry milk to the nipple) and lobules (glands that make milk).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.:A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002:Involving the use of histology or histological techniques.

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.
Involving the use of histology or histological techniques.

Property.preferredDefinition: Confirmed; having been established or verified.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
